issue.title: liboqs installation problem
issue.body:
Hi, I tried to install the liboqs but on `ninja run_tests` it fails on tests/test_style.py::test_style at 97%, after that i tried the command `ninja install` but it returns the following error: 
```

[0/1] Install the project...
-- Install configuration: ""
-- Installing: /usr/local/lib/liboqs.a
CMake Error at src/cmake_install.cmake:41 (file):
  file INSTALL cannot copy file "/home/pg41101/liboqs/build/lib/liboqs.a" to
  "/usr/local/lib/liboqs.a".
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  cmake_install.cmake:42 (include)


FAILED: CMakeFiles/install.util
cd /home/pg41101/liboqs/build && /usr/bin/cmake -P cmake_install.cmake
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```

But running the same command with root it works: 

```
[0/1] Install the project...
-- Install configuration: ""
-- Installing: /usr/local/lib/liboqs.a
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/oqs.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/common.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/rand.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/aes.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sha2.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sha3.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_bike.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_frodokem.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_sike.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_picnic.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_qtesla.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_classic_mceliece.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_kyber.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_ledacrypt.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_newhope.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_ntru.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_saber.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/kem_threebears.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_dilithium.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_falcon.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_mqdss.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_rainbow.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/sig_sphincs.h
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/include/oqs/oqsconfig.h

```
Honestly I don't even know if is correctly installed but my main reason to install this library is to use it with the python3 wrappers **liboqs-python**, so after I clone the the project I ran the command `oqs/oqs.py` and it returns the following message `No liboqs shared libraries found`.

I have very poor experience on installing/compiling libraries, would appreciate if anyone could help me or guide me to install liboqs successfully so i can use **liboqs-python**.

Thank you.

comment.body:
Thank you for your response! the problem of test_style failing was indeed the `astyle`, but after installing it another test fails `tests/test_namespace.py::test_namespace`. 

The `<DIR>` in `-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=<DIR>`, what should the location be to successfully install, I currently have the project under my user folder... 

Once I installed the `liboqs`, the `liboqs-python` should be in any specific path, and to specify the `LIBOQS_INSTALL_PATH` i only need to run this command `LIBOQS_INSTALL_PATH="/usr/local/bin/liboqs.so"` with the correct path to the `liboqs.so` correct?

issue.title: Properly namespace the picnic internal functions
issue.body: Addresses issue #666.

comment.body: Still failing on some platform; not sure why...

issue.title: TLS hybrid draft update
issue.body:
1. I've updated the KeyShare format to match the Feb 2020 TLS draft. 

2. I've created a new class `ClassicalOQSKeyShare`, for hybrid key-exchange. This class can be instantiated and used any pair of group ID's (OQS or otherwise) and does not need to keep track of the individual algorithms' ciphertext or shared secret sizes. For example, the code has 

```C
New<ClassicalOQSKeyShare>(SSL_CURVE_P256_FRODO640AES, SSL_CURVE_SECP256R1, OQS_KEM_alg_frodokem_640_aes)
```

but if we wanted to use `X25519`, we'd just have to change this to 
```C
New<ClassicalOQSKeyShare>(SSL_CURVE_P256_FRODO640AES, SSL_CURVE_X25519, OQS_KEM_alg_frodokem_640_aes)
```

and if we wanted Level 3 security, we'd just need to invoke 

```C
New<ClassicalOQSKeyShare>(SSL_CURVE_P256_FRODO640AES, SSL_CURVE_SECP384R1, OQS_KEM_alg_frodokem_976_aes)
```

comment.body:
We don't yet have a test-suite for interoperability testing, but that is on my TODO list. I'll get to it once I'm done with https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl/issues/9 and merging [pq-sigs](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl/tree/pq-sigs) in (the branch has a significant overhaul of the test suite). 

As for build instructions, you have to pass in the `DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=OFF` flag. I'll update the README.

issue.title: Update hybrid KeyShare format
issue.body: Update the KeyShare format for hybrid key-exchanges to reflect [draft-stebila-tls-hybrid-design-03](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-stebila-tls-hybrid-design-03#section-3.2)

comment.body: Closed by https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl/pull/11

issue.body:
1. I've updated the KeyShare format to match the Feb 2020 TLS draft. 

2. I've created a new class `ClassicalOQSKeyShare`, for hybrid key-exchange. This class can be instantiated and used any pair of group ID's (OQS or otherwise) and does not need to keep track of the individual algorithms' ciphertext or shared secret sizes. For example, the code has 

```C
New<ClassicalOQSKeyShare>(SSL_CURVE_P256_FRODO640AES, SSL_CURVE_SECP256R1, OQS_KEM_alg_frodokem_640_aes)
```

but if we wanted to use `X25519`, we'd just have to change this to 
```C

```

and if we wanted Level 3 security, we'd just need to invoke 

```C

```

issue.title: build-type Optimized reactivated
issue.body:
Without this, `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Optimized` doesn't execute (correctly, i.e., CPU feature defines are not set correctly). 

Going forward, might it be an idea to add to the CI test suite validation for different build types? Possibly performance checks (`Optimized`-built test results should be better than `Debug`-built test runs)? I admit I don't know how/whether this is possible (tests between job results), though.

comment.body: @baentsch I've seen this error before, and I've written about it https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/654#issuecomment-598131843. It looks like the optimized implementation of keccak does not work on Windows.

issue.title: Use of cpu_features from #654 breaks cross-compilation
issue.body:
cpu_features's build doesn't work with the Windows or Raspberry Pi cross-compiling toolchains. CMake fails to run successfully in each case but for different reasons. Build host is running Ubuntu 18.04 and current tip of master is 9897b49.

The Raspberry Pi build complains that it's being built for a non-x86 platform, which it is. The Windows build complains that it doesn't understand the `-rdynamic` command line option to the C compiler.

Outputs of each run of CMake are attached.

[raspbuild.log](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4381743/raspbuild.log)
[winbuild.log](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4381744/winbuild.log)

comment.body: Looks like `cpu_features` doesn't support cross-compilation. I can try to make a patch for their library.

comment.body:
CircleCI's absence is strange indeed. Could you apply this [patch.txt](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4382084/patch.txt)? It should fix set the `OQS_USE_*` variables if `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE` is `Optimized` or quit with a fatal error otherwise. I've also modified the top-level CMakeLists.txt to include `cpu_features` only if the build type is `Optimized`.

Maybe another commit will kickstart CircleCI.

issue.title: Use of cpu_features from #654 breaks cross-compilation
issue.body:
cpu_features's build doesn't work with the Windows or Raspberry Pi cross-compiling toolchains. CMake fails to run successfully in each case but for different reasons. Build host is running Ubuntu 18.04 and current tip of master is 9897b49.

The Raspberry Pi build complains that it's being built for a non-x86 platform, which it is. The Windows build complains that it doesn't understand the `-rdynamic` command line option to the C compiler.

Outputs of each run of CMake are attached.

[raspbuild.log](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4381743/raspbuild.log)
[winbuild.log](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4381744/winbuild.log)

comment.body:
Got further this time with the patch.

Raspberry Pi build: Weirdly complains that it couldn't find OpenSSL, saying: found suitable version "1.1.1", minimum required is "1.1.1"
Windows build: Complains that there's no setting for the resource compiler (CMake Error: CMAKE_RC_COMPILER not set, after EnableLanguage).

New full logs attached.
[winbuild.log](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4382471/winbuild.log)
[raspbuild.log](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4382473/raspbuild.log)

[winbuild.log](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4381744/winbuild.log)

comment.body:
You need to fix the CMake call
`$ cmake -GNinja -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=../.CMake/toolchain_rasppi.cmake -DUSE_OPENSSL=OFF ..`
Replace `-DUSE_OPENSSL=OFF` with `-DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=OFF`.

As for Windows, I'm not sure, but try to apply this [patch](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/files/4382566/patch.txt)

comment.body: Could you remove `-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Optimized` from `appveyor_build.bat` for MSVC and add a TODO note? Could you also fix the comment [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/master/.CMake/toolchain_rasppi.cmake#L2) by changing `USE_OPENSSL` to `OQS_USE_OPENSSL`?

comment.body:
Using `-DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=OFF` now lets the Raspberry Pi cross-build complete successfully. Can you update the [cross-compiling wiki](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Platform-specific-notes-for-building-liboqs) and the comment in the toolchain file?

Both patches together now allow the Windows build to succeed as well.

Thanks!

issue.title: Run the test_kem and test_sig tests on a thread when possible
issue.body:
Algorithms with large stack usage cause problems when running in threads (e.g., #608, https://travis-ci.com/github/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-cpp/jobs/299650240).  This PR moves the tests in `test_kem` and `test_sig` onto a thread when compiling with clang or gcc, so as to detect these failures at the liboqs level, rather than leaving it to downstream sub-projects.

Note that the following schemes are currently failing:
```
Classic-McEliece-348864
Classic-McEliece-348864f
Classic-McEliece-460896
Classic-McEliece-460896f
Classic-McEliece-6688128
Classic-McEliece-6688128f
Classic-McEliece-6960119
Classic-McEliece-6960119f
Classic-McEliece-8192128
Classic-McEliece-8192128f
LEDAcryptKEM-LT52
Rainbow-IIIc-Classic
Rainbow-IIIc-Cyclic
Rainbow-IIIc-Cyclic-Compressed
Rainbow-Vc-Classic
Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic
Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic-Compressed
```

I'm not sure how to approach solving this.  Do we disable these algorithms by default?  Try to rewrite them so they're on the heap, rather than the stack?  Try to enlarge the stack in how all our subprojects are compiled so that they can be run (but then people might encounter this bad behaviour outside of our build)?

Advice welcome, @vsoftco @xvzcf @christianpaquin @thomwiggers @baentsch.

comment.body: @dstebila will review by Friday
